slide.text: + Born on October 13, 1912, in Budapest, Hungary
+ Family moved to Germany when he was 5 years old
+ Graduated from the University of Berlin with a degree in geography and cartography
+ Received his Ph.D. in geography from the University of Marburg
+ Worked at the University of Wisconsin-Madison as a professor of geography and cartography
+ Founded the Department of Geography and developed the graduate program in Geographic Information Science (GIS)
+ Published numerous papers on GIS, spatial analysis, and map design
+ Co-founded the Journal of Geographic Information System (JGIS) with Dr. Jack D. Johnson
+ Retired from the University of Wisconsin-Madison in 1986
+ Moved to California and continued to work on GIS research and consulting
+ Passed away on May 27, 2005, at the age of 92
+ Raisz, E. (1963). A spatial analysis of urban land use patterns. Journal of the American Planning Association, 19(4), 345-358.
+ Raisz, E. (1971). The relationship between residential location and metropolitan development. Environmental Psychology, 1(4), 423-436.
+ Raisz, E., & Johnson, J. D. (1980). Geographic information systems: A new tool for urban analysis. Urban Studies, 17(3), 257-266.
+ Raisz, E. (1982). The science of spatial analysis. Journal of Geography, 81(4), 145-156.
+ Raisz, E., & Muller, M. J. (1978). Spatial interaction models for urban and regional systems. Progress in Physical Geography, 2(1), 35-51.
+ Raisz, E., & Shelton, T. A. (Eds.). (1987). Geographic information systems: Applications in the earth sciences. John Wiley & Sons.

Erwin Raisz was a pioneer in the field of Geographic Information Science and his contributions to the development of GIS technology have had a lasting impact on the field. His work laid the foundation for modern spatial analysis and his legacy continues to inspire new generations of researchers and practitioners.
